XMLHttpRequest_API.summary: The XMLHttpRequest API enables web apps to make HTTP requests to web servers and receive the responses programmatically using JavaScript. This in turn enables a website to update just part of a page with data from the server, rather than having to navigate to a whole new page. This practice is also sometimes known as AJAX.

remarks.para: The Fetch API is the more flexible and powerful replacement for the XMLHttpRequest API. The Fetch API uses {{jsxref("Promise", "promises", "", 1)}} instead of events to handle asynchronous responses, integrates well with service workers, and supports advanced aspects of HTTP such as CORS. For these reasons, the Fetch API is usually used in modern web apps instead of .

XMLHttpRequest_APIHTML_in_XMLHttpRequest.summary: The W3C specification adds HTML parsing support to , which originally supported only {{Glossary("XML")}} parsing. This feature allows Web apps to obtain an HTML resource as a parsed {{Glossary("DOM")}} using XMLHttpRequest.

remarks.para: To get an overview of how to use XMLHttpRequest in general, see Using XMLHttpRequest.

XMLHttpRequest_APISynchronous_and_Asynch.summary: supports both synchronous and asynchronous communications. In general, however, asynchronous requests should be preferred to synchronous requests for performance reasons.

remarks.para: Synchronous requests block the execution of code which causes "freezing" on the screen and an unresponsive user experience.

XMLHttpRequest_APIUsing_FormData_Objects.summary: The FormData object lets you compile a set of key/value pairs to send using the Fetch or XMLHttpRequest API. It is primarily intended for use in sending form data, but can be used independently from forms in order to transmit keyed data. The transmitted data is in the same format that the form's method would use to send the data if the form's encoding type were set to multipart/form-data.

XMLHttpRequest_APIUsing_XMLHttpRequest.summary: In this guide, we'll take a look at how to use to issue HTTP requests in order to exchange data between the website and a server.

remarks.para: Examples of both common and more obscure use cases for XMLHttpRequest are included.
